links.evidence: C4b, CfB, and C3 all had significantly higher abundances in the lungs of mice infected with a lethal dose of SARS-CoV MA15 than in those of mice infected with a sublethal dose (Fig. 1A).
C4b, CfB, and C3 all had significantly higher abundances in the lungs of mice infected with a lethal dose of SARS-CoV MA15 than in those of mice infected with a sublethal dose (Fig. 1A).
C4b, CfB, and C3 all had significantly higher abundances in the lungs of mice infected with a lethal dose of SARS-CoV MA15 than in those of mice infected with a sublethal dose (Fig. 1A).

C3 activation products (C3 fragments C3a, C3b, iC3b, C3dg, and C3c) were detected by Western blotting in lung tissue of SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice, but not in control mice, as early as 1 day postinfection (dpi) (Fig. 1B), confirming that SARS-CoV MA15 infection activates the complement pathway.
Western blot analysis showed increased levels of C3a-derived fragments in the serum, indicating systemic complement activation in SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice at 2 dpi (Fig. 7A).

C3 activation products (C3 fragments C3a, C3b, iC3b, C3dg, and C3c) were detected by Western blotting in lung tissue of SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice, but not in control mice, as early as 1 day postinfection (dpi) (Fig. 1B), confirming that SARS-CoV MA15 infection activates the complement pathway.

C3 activation products (C3 fragments C3a, C3b, iC3b, C3dg, and C3c) were detected by Western blotting in lung tissue of SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice, but not in control mice, as early as 1 day postinfection (dpi) (Fig. 1B), confirming that SARS-CoV MA15 infection activates the complement pathway.

C3 activation products (C3 fragments C3a, C3b, iC3b, C3dg, and C3c) were detected by Western blotting in lung tissue of SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice, but not in control mice, as early as 1 day postinfection (dpi) (Fig. 1B), confirming that SARS-CoV MA15 infection activates the complement pathway.

Control mice exhibited approximately 15% transient weight loss, with peak weight loss at day 3 postinfection (Fig. 2A). In contrast, the C3 â/â mice were significantly protected from infection, with no significant weight loss evident at any time point.

All three metrics have been shown to change significantly following SARS-CoV MA15 infection, with Penh and EF50 increasing following infection and RPEF decreasing. Combined, these measurements show that SARS-CoV MA15-infected animals have altered exhalation patterns in their breathing.

C3 â/â mice exhibit a decreased change in Penh and EF50 levels following SARS-CoV MA15 infection relative to those of infected C57BL/6J control mice; however, RPEF values were similar between infection conditions (Fig. 2C to E).

All three metrics have been shown to change significantly following SARS-CoV MA15 infection, with Penh and EF50 increasing following infection and RPEF decreasing. Combined, these measurements show that SARS-CoV MA15-infected animals have altered exhalation patterns in their breathing.

C3 â/â mice exhibit a decreased change in Penh and EF50 levels following SARS-CoV MA15 infection relative to those of infected C57BL/6J control mice; however, RPEF values were similar between infection conditions (Fig. 2C to E).
C3 â/â mice exhibited more airspace inflammation, including eosinophils, at 2 dpi than their wild-type controls, although this relationship was reversed later in infection.

At 4 dpi, C57BL/6J mice displayed pronounced lung pathology, including inflammatory cells in the large airway and parenchyma, perivascular cuffing, thickening of the interstitial membrane, and low levels of intra-alveolar edema.
C3 â/â mice exhibited more airspace inflammation, including eosinophils, at 2 dpi than their wild-type controls, although this relationship was reversed later in infection.

In parallel with humans exhibiting lung pathology, C3 â/â mice exhibited significant pulmonary infiltration following SARS-CoV MA15 infection, but this inflammation was reduced relative to that observed in wild-type mice.

At 4 dpi, C57BL/6J mice displayed pronounced lung pathology, including inflammatory cells in the large airway and parenchyma, perivascular cuffing, thickening of the interstitial membrane, and low levels of intra-alveolar edema.

At 4 dpi, C57BL/6J mice displayed pronounced lung pathology, including inflammatory cells in the large airway and parenchyma, perivascular cuffing, thickening of the interstitial membrane, and low levels of intra-alveolar edema.

At both 2 and 4 dpi, we observed scattered positive staining for complement in the lungs of SARS-CoV MA15-infected mice, suggesting that local tissue damage might contribute to SARS-CoV pathogenesis (Fig. 4)

Consistently with what was observed in human SARS-CoV patients (25), lymphopenia was observed in the lungs of both SARS-CoV MA15-infected C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice with reduced percentages of B cells (Fig. 5A) and CD4 T cells relative to those in mock-infected mice following infection.

Consistently with what was observed in human SARS-CoV patients (25), lymphopenia was observed in the lungs of both SARS-CoV MA15-infected C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice with reduced percentages of B cells (Fig. 5A) and CD4 T cells relative to those in mock-infected mice following infection.

Consistently with what was observed in human SARS-CoV patients (25), lymphopenia was observed in the lungs of both SARS-CoV MA15-infected C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice with reduced percentages of B cells (Fig. 5A) and CD4 T cells relative to those in mock-infected mice following infection.

Despite similar overall lymphocyte levels, small but significant differences were observed in levels of T cell activation between infected C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice; both CD4 and CD8 T cells in C3 â/â mice expressed more Ki-67 (Fig. 5C and D), an intracellular marker of proliferation, than those in C57BL/6J controls.

Analysis of myeloid cells in the lung showed that infected C56BL/6J mice had significantly higher levels of neutrophils, particularly nonactivated neutrophils, in the lung than infected C3 â/â mice (Fig. 5B and E).

Furthermore, inflammatory monocytes, which have previously been associated with increased SARS-CoV MA15 pathogenesis (26), were significantly increased in the lungs of wild-type mice but not C3 â/â mice (Fig. 5B).
Finally, we observed significantly more dendritic cells and alveolar macrophages in the lungs of SARS-CoV MA15-infected C3 â/â mice than in the lungs of infected C57BL/6J mice.
Finally, we observed significantly more dendritic cells and alveolar macrophages in the lungs of SARS-CoV MA15-infected C3 â/â mice than in the lungs of infected C57BL/6J mice.

MIP1a, MIP1b, and MCP1 are all highly expressed in the lung following SARS-CoV MA15 infection of both C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice (Fig. 6A), indicating that some inflammatory signaling remains intact in the absence of C3.

MIP1a, MIP1b, and MCP1 are all highly expressed in the lung following SARS-CoV MA15 infection of both C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice (Fig. 6A), indicating that some inflammatory signaling remains intact in the absence of C3.

MIP1a, MIP1b, and MCP1 are all highly expressed in the lung following SARS-CoV MA15 infection of both C57BL/6J and C3 â/â mice (Fig. 6A), indicating that some inflammatory signaling remains intact in the absence of C3.
Both MCP-1 and RANTES levels were elevated in the serum following infection, regardless of mouse genetic background (Fig. 7B).

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), interleukin 6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-a), and IL-1a comprised a group of cytokines and chemokines that were more highly produced in the lungs of C57BL/6J mice than in C3 â/â mice (Fig. 6B), all peaking at 2 days postinfection.

However, numerous cytokines and chemokines, such as IL-5, G-CSF, and KC (keratinocyte chemoattractant or CXCL1) were present in significantly higher abundance in the lungs of C57BL/6J mice than in those of C3 knockout mice (Fig. 7C).
